Legal_Issue: Assessment of humanitarian and compassionate grounds for exemption from applying for permanent residence outside Canada
Governing_Law: Section 72 of IRPA (Immigration and Refugee Protection Act)
Evidence_Assessment: Applicants' years of residence in Canada, claimed political risks upon removal, ties to Canada, country conditions
Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship
Legal_Rule: Hardship must be unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate to succeed on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Grounds_for_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds due to hardship from removal and ties in Canada
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Decision considered all relevant factors and evidence
Key_Evidence_Considered: Duration of residence in Canada, lack of refugee status, political risk claims, familial and community ties
Applicant_Challenge: Officer erred in assessing humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Defendant_Response: Officer found no unusual hardship based on evidence and country conditions
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, personal circumstances, country condition reports
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of refusal and grant of permanent residency on humanitarian grounds
Claimant_Status: Applicants denied refugee status and H&C exemption
Pending_Relief_or_Application: Permanent residence application under H&C grounds
Governing_Rule: Section 72 IRPA allows judicial review of immigration decisions; hardship must meet threshold
